1568735040_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_1002_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Have you ever looked at those blocklists? The site you're looking at is actually KxoNet, not KxoID. KxoNet is a collection of many services, including Plugin Store, KxoID, KxoBlock and so on. And those blocklists weren't even finished AFAIK.

Having a CA run by someone who's not a hardcore free speech activist is not advisable in case they start preventing people from getting certs for stuff they said elsewhere or certificate revocation becomes a feature.
Or worse, begin doxing people with privileged information obtained through the required plugins.

>Krixano left ZeroNet and I doubt he'll return anytime soon, so you can't say that KxoID is hosted by non-hardcode speech activists
He's the one with the private keys to update the code for the site (and maybe associate plugins, I don't know who controls those). So even if technically the code is being run on random people's computers, what code is being run is controlled by him or whoever he decided to lend the keys to.
>Also, certificate revocation isn't possible the way ZeroNet works currently
That's why I said "if it ever becomes a feature".
>and, anyways, old certificates can never be revoked.
Why not? Just make ZeroNet fetch a blacklist signed by the CA from somewhere. All it would take is nofish pushing an update that adds that feature, or the maintainers for the required plugin to get KxoID certs (which again, for all I know might be controlled by the same guy who set up KxoID) which would prevent people who have themselves gotten KxoID certs to recognize blacklisted users as valid.
By making these lists he expressed at the very least an intent to make it easy for other users to block people he disagrees with. Making it mandatory for people who use his ID service to subscribe to those blacklists is just a step away.
>Finally, there's no way to avoid requests being decrypted by the registrars
I never mentioned encryption. I'm talking about the plugins pinging a clearnet address with your IP, your master seed, your bank account, or what have you. Plguins (at least as far as I understand it) are omnipotent. I wouldn't really want to have somebody who subscribes to leftist ideals so much that he goes out of his way to maintain wrongthink lists to be able to push arbitrary code to my computer.
Especially with all the stuff that's going on right now, case in point being Stallman's words being spun by the media to get him kicked from the FSF.
How can I trust that a guy who makes lists of people saying bad things about the jews won't get contacted by a journalist some day promising to make him famous or give him some money if he doxes all those bad people over there saying bad things about the jews?

> [glightstar](#comment_158_14K7EydgyeP84L1NKaAHBZTPQCev8BbqCy): "globally forced blocklist system" (or however you want to call it)
I'm not talking about a global blacklist. I'm talking about cert providers being able to revoke the certificates they have emitted in the past. Which by itself would probably be a reasonable feature.

> [gitcenter](#comment_1010_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Well, that applies to ZeroID and other providers as well
What? Where are those political related blocklists compiled by nofish?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1011_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Hey, look! Krixano just created a literally empty blocklist, he might add users there and force others to use it! And nofish doesn't have it, see? Oh wow, nofish just created an empty blocklist too, but that should be just a test, right? Oh, look, nofish just added a few people there but he might have done that accidentally, right? And where's KxoNet blocklists now?
What list has nofish created?
>Still empty? Hm, might be just a weird plan on Krixano's side, I'm sure he'll force it soon...
I didn't say it was a weird plan. I specifically mentioned some journalist contacting him in the future and him being agreeable because of his beliefs.

> [gitcenter](#comment_1013_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Hey, don't think of Krixano that bad. I mean, Krixano at least has some views and shows them, while nofish is just a shady person that tends to be away from his project. I'd believe an open yet weird person more than a shady one (three-letter agencies being a good illustration).
So you're just going to dodge the question and not say what blacklists has nofish created?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1006_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): BackgroundProcessing plugin (it's written by me and it's open-source, so you can be sure there are no issues there) makes sure that 0background.py code is executed safely without any vulnerability.

What method do you use to run Python code without that code being able to do anything harmful?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1017_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Huh, that's an interesting question. Basically, it's something like sandboxing: the code is only allowed to access a small set of features. [...]

How are you deleting the underscore underscore something something underscore underscore properties of every object in the object tree that you need to pass to the scripts to do their job?
Anyways, if this does indeed work, then krixano can still overwrite PeerMessage on his store, right?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1021_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): I'm not deleting them, as there's o way to delete them. Instead, I don't allow the scripts to access them (i.e. var.__attr__ is replaced by getattr(var, "__attr__") or similar). [...]

How does someone set up a script to be run by BackgroundProcessing?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1021_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): I'm not deleting them, as there's o way to delete them. Instead, I don't allow the scripts to access them (i.e. var.__attr__ is replaced by getattr(var, "__attr__") or similar). [...]

So if accessing attributes is allowed only if they're on a whitelist, why does the code contain the lines
```
        # Now do something to prevent object.__subclasses__() hacks and others
        if (
            isinstance(node, ast.Attribute) and
            ((
                node.attr.startswith("__") and
                node.attr.endswith("__")
            ) or (
                node.attr.startswith("func_")
            ))
        ):
```
which seem to imply they need to be handled specifically?
on `sandboxer/__init__.py`

> [gitcenter](#comment_1033_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): There are two kinds of special attributes in Python: those starting and ending with two underscores, and those starting with func_ (though the latter might've been removed in Python 3, idk). All other attributes are safe. So my code only carefully handles special attributes.

So the part that needs to be in the whitelist is the top level object, and then any method inside that object can be accessed as long as it doesn't begin with ``__``?
If anyone leaks the private key, does that mean KxoID basically becomes useless?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1068_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Not really. There are actually 3 keys: one for KxoID site, one for level-1 usernames and one for level-2 usernames. Registrars only get the 3rd key. It's enough to register a username, but it can't be used for anything else. Also, most requests are handled by level-1 registrars actually (namely, Krixano and me), so if the 3rd key gets leaked, we'll only have a small part of users that were invalidated. We can then: [...]

And how are you able to have two private keys with a single cert_signers entry?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1069_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): While there is a single cert_signers entry, an ID provider entry content is actually an array, so you can specify several keys for a single ID provider.

Yeah, but ZeroTalk only has one
```"kxoid.bit": ["12F5SvxoPR128aiudte78h8pY7mobroG6V"],```
And what do you mean by "manually re-register"? Do you mean every user would have to re-register?

1568749254_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEG.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_1030_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Ah, so a nofish-controlled service is awesome, and many-people-controlled service is bad? 

That might be the case. If any developer who contributed good code was allowed to have power over the project it would become rather easy to subvert. Just invest enough into improving it until you have majority control and then begin taking bad decisions. Sorry to insist, but just look at how RMS was kicked out of the foundation he himself created, Linus was forced to step off from his leadership position, F-Droid was forced to kick out Gab, etc. Ideally nofish wouldn't have his real life identity out there, but at least now that his identity is known he should refuse to make concessions to astroturfers trying to get him to do stuff like Theo de Raadt does (not saying you are one, just saying giving out control makes their job easier).
Probably the only reason the Tor project has remained censorship free is that government agents need it to remain hidden when collecting intelligence online.

> [filips](#comment_203_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): It shouldn't be that any developer who contributed code has full access to development management.

> [gitcenter](#comment_1038_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Well, I kinda understand your point, but it's not just about people who contributed good code and it's not just about having power over the project.

Sure, I'm just saying. nofish might have been slow to react to vulnerabilities but he is more or less a known entity and so far hasn't censored anyone even in his own sites (like this one). It's a trade off between risk of policies changing and fixing bugs faster and possibly more features.
That doesn't have anything to do with KxoID, true, I just bring it up because OP did.

> [kaffie](#comment_1107_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): KaffieID is currently the only decentralized zeronet id provider

So does it do any kind of rate-limiting or not?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1075_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): It doesn't, it's impossible to rate-limit KaffieID-like ID providers.

Have the ZeroNet developers put any thought into moving to a web of trust model? That would allow only peers who meet a certain criteria (for example, seed ratio or proof of work) to be able to issue certificates, each one with his own private key, and to be able to rate limit or even put them behind a captcha.

1568498469_1JyYutdv87sYHdinuhLTzzpJAVsua.body:
> [hardee](#comment_40_13Azsbvu9LH6rFLn5dUE7DEuRTQ59bYt9H): Lainchan doxxed the person responsible for misconstructing RMS' words and you can even see that in the media reports; furthermore the guy was a US Govt Contractor. Hell take me ZeroNet, I expected more from you. Guy was wildly autistic and wasn't a good representative of Linux as a whole but his passion for Free Software should be commended at the very least.

They didn't dox her. She made a Medium post with her real name and linked to her WP blog in the profile page, mentioning the company in the "about me" page of said blog.
